name: vicia-faba
wildlife-value: Bees, wasps and lady beetles are attracted to the flowers.
edibility: Faba bean is widely grown for its nutritious seeds and pods. The dry, mature seeds are popular in dishes throughout the Middle East, Mediterranean countries, China and Ethiopia and in many other countries the green immature seeds and pods are eaten as a vegetable. It is also used in animal feed for pigs, horses, poultry and pigeons.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: The fruit is a narrowly oblong flattened pod up to 11 inches long containing up to 6 seeds. The seeds are .5 to 1 inch in diameter and are oval and compressed. The colors of the seeds range from brown to reddish or green.
flower-description: The stalked flowers are unbranched racemes with 1-6 flowers that are fragrant and resemble those of a pea bloom. Petals are white with the outermost one being marked with a purplish or brown blotch.
leaf-description: Each stem is composed of 2-6 leaflets that are 4 by 1.5 inches. Each leaf has conspicuous stipules (appendages at the base of the leaf) which are toothed at the margins and vary widely in shape.
stem-description: It has a course, stout, square, hollow stem having no branches.
poison-symptoms: Persons ingesting numerous seeds and having a genetic predisposition to favism may develop a blood disorder (hemolytic anemia) by eating the beans, or even by walking through a field where the plants are in flower.
uses: A fiber extracted from the stems is used for making soap.
